trans-unit.source: Indexers
trans-unit.target: Indexers

trans-unit.source: Indexers
trans-unit.target: Indexers

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Indexers
trans-unit.target: Indexers

trans-unit.source: *Indexers* are similar to properties.
trans-unit.target: *Indexers* are similar to properties.

trans-unit.source: In many ways indexers build on the same language features as [properties](properties.md).
trans-unit.target: In many ways indexers build on the same language features as [properties](properties.md).

trans-unit.source: Indexers enable *indexed* properties: properties referenced using one or more arguments.
trans-unit.target: Indexers enable *indexed* properties: properties referenced using one or more arguments.

trans-unit.source: Those arguments provide an index into some collection of values.
trans-unit.target: Those arguments provide an index into some collection of values.

trans-unit.source: Indexer Syntax
trans-unit.target: Indexer Syntax

trans-unit.source: You access an indexer through a variable name and square brackets .
trans-unit.target: You access an indexer through a variable name and square brackets .

trans-unit.source: You place the indexer arguments inside the brackets:
trans-unit.target: You place the indexer arguments inside the brackets:

trans-unit.source: You declare indexers using the `this` keyword as the property name, and declaring the arguments within square brackets.
trans-unit.target: You declare indexers using the `this` keyword as the property name, and declaring the arguments within square brackets.

trans-unit.source: This declaration would match the usage shown in the previous paragraph:
trans-unit.target: This declaration would match the usage shown in the previous paragraph:

trans-unit.source: From this initial example, you can see the relationship between the syntax for properties and for indexers.
trans-unit.target: From this initial example, you can see the relationship between the syntax for properties and for indexers.

trans-unit.source: This analogy carries through most of the syntax rules for indexers.
trans-unit.target: This analogy carries through most of the syntax rules for indexers.

trans-unit.source: Indexers can have any valid access modifiers (public, protected internal, protected, internal, or private).
trans-unit.target: Indexers can have any valid access modifiers (public, protected internal, protected, internal, or private).

trans-unit.source: They may be sealed, virtual, or abstract.
trans-unit.target: They may be sealed, virtual, or abstract.

trans-unit.source: As with properties, you can specify different access modifiers for the get and set accesssors in an indexer.
trans-unit.target: As with properties, you can specify different access modifiers for the get and set accesssors in an indexer.

trans-unit.source: You may also specify read-only indexers (by omitting the set accessor), or write-only indexers (by omitting the get accessor).
trans-unit.target: You may also specify read-only indexers (by omitting the set accessor), or write-only indexers (by omitting the get accessor).

trans-unit.source: You can apply almost everything you learn from working with properties to indexers.
trans-unit.target: You can apply almost everything you learn from working with properties to indexers.

trans-unit.source: The only exception to that rule is *auto implemented properties*.
trans-unit.target: The only exception to that rule is *auto implemented properties*.

trans-unit.source: The compiler cannot always generate the correct storage for an indexer.
trans-unit.target: The compiler cannot always generate the correct storage for an indexer.

trans-unit.source: The presence of arguments to reference an item in a set of items distinguishes indexers from properties.
trans-unit.target: The presence of arguments to reference an item in a set of items distinguishes indexers from properties.

trans-unit.source: You may define mulitple indexers on a type, as long as the argument lists for each indexer is unique.
trans-unit.target: You may define mulitple indexers on a type, as long as the argument lists for each indexer is unique.

trans-unit.source: Let's explore different scenarios where you might use one or more indexers in a class definition.
trans-unit.target: Let's explore different scenarios where you might use one or more indexers in a class definition.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios
trans-unit.target: Scenarios

trans-unit.source: You would define *indexers* in your type when its API models some collection where you define the arguments to that collection.
trans-unit.target: You would define *indexers* in your type when its API models some collection where you define the arguments to that collection.

trans-unit.source: Your indexers may or may not map directly to the collection types that are part of the .NET core framework.
trans-unit.target: Your indexers may or may not map directly to the collection types that are part of the .NET core framework.

trans-unit.source: Your type may have other responsibilities in addition to modeling a collection.
trans-unit.target: Your type may have other responsibilities in addition to modeling a collection.

trans-unit.source: Indexers enable you to provide the API that matches your type's abstraction without exposing the inner details of how the values for that abstraction are stored or computed.
trans-unit.target: Indexers enable you to provide the API that matches your type's abstraction without exposing the inner details of how the values for that abstraction are stored or computed.

trans-unit.source: Let's walk through some of the common scenarios for using *indexers*.
trans-unit.target: Let's walk through some of the common scenarios for using *indexers*.

trans-unit.source: The code for all the samples is available at the core-docs [GitHub repository](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs).
trans-unit.target: The code for all the samples is available at the core-docs [GitHub repository](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs).

trans-unit.source: Or, you can access the [sample folder](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs/tree/master/samples/csharp-language/indexers) directly.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can access the [sample folder](https://github.com/dotnet/core-docs/tree/master/samples/csharp-language/indexers) directly.

trans-unit.source: Arrays and Vectors
trans-unit.target: Arrays and Vectors

trans-unit.source: One of the most common scenarios for creating indexers is when your type models an array, or a vector.
trans-unit.target: One of the most common scenarios for creating indexers is when your type models an array, or a vector.

trans-unit.source: You can create an indexer to model an ordered list of data.
trans-unit.target: You can create an indexer to model an ordered list of data.

trans-unit.source: The advantage of creating your own indexer is that you can define the storage for that collection to suit your needs.
trans-unit.target: The advantage of creating your own indexer is that you can define the storage for that collection to suit your needs.

trans-unit.source: Imagine a scenario where your type models historical data that is too large to load into memory at once.
trans-unit.target: Imagine a scenario where your type models historical data that is too large to load into memory at once.

trans-unit.source: You need to load and unload sections of the collection based on usage.
trans-unit.target: You need to load and unload sections of the collection based on usage.

trans-unit.source: The example following models this behavior.
trans-unit.target: The example following models this behavior.

trans-unit.source: It reports on how many data points exist.
trans-unit.target: It reports on how many data points exist.

trans-unit.source: It creates pages to hold sections of the data on demand.
trans-unit.target: It creates pages to hold sections of the data on demand.

trans-unit.source: It removes pages from memory to make room for pages needed by more recent requests.
trans-unit.target: It removes pages from memory to make room for pages needed by more recent requests.

trans-unit.source: You can follow this design idiom to model any sort of collection where there are good reasons not to load the entire set of data into an in- memory collection.
trans-unit.target: You can follow this design idiom to model any sort of collection where there are good reasons not to load the entire set of data into an in- memory collection.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the `Page` class is a private nested class that is not part of the public interface.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the `Page` class is a private nested class that is not part of the public interface.

trans-unit.source: Those details are hidden from any users of this class.
trans-unit.target: Those details are hidden from any users of this class.

trans-unit.source: Dictionaries
trans-unit.target: Dictionaries

trans-unit.source: Another common scenario is when you need to model a dictionary or a map.
trans-unit.target: Another common scenario is when you need to model a dictionary or a map.

trans-unit.source: This scenario is when your type stores values based on key, typically text keys.
trans-unit.target: This scenario is when your type stores values based on key, typically text keys.

trans-unit.source: This example creates a dictionary that maps command line arguments to [lamdba expressions](delegates-overview.md) that manage those options.
trans-unit.target: This example creates a dictionary that maps command line arguments to [lamdba expressions](delegates-overview.md) that manage those options.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows two classes: an `ArgsActions` class that maps a command line option to an `Action` delegate, and an `ArgsProcessor` that uses the `ArgsActions` to execute each `Action` when it encounters that option.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows two classes: an `ArgsActions` class that maps a command line option to an `Action` delegate, and an `ArgsProcessor` that uses the `ArgsActions` to execute each `Action` when it encounters that option.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the `ArgsAction` collection maps closely to the underlying collection.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the `ArgsAction` collection maps closely to the underlying collection.

trans-unit.source: The `get` determines if a given option has been configured.
trans-unit.target: The `get` determines if a given option has been configured.

trans-unit.source: If so, it returns the `Action` associated with that option.
trans-unit.target: If so, it returns the `Action` associated with that option.

trans-unit.source: If not, it returns an `Action` that does nothing.
trans-unit.target: If not, it returns an `Action` that does nothing.

trans-unit.source: The public accessor does not include a `set` accessor.
trans-unit.target: The public accessor does not include a `set` accessor.

trans-unit.source: Rather, the design using a public method for setting options.
trans-unit.target: Rather, the design using a public method for setting options.

trans-unit.source: Multi-Dimensional Maps
trans-unit.target: Multi-Dimensional Maps

trans-unit.source: You can create indexers that use multiple arguments.
trans-unit.target: You can create indexers that use multiple arguments.

trans-unit.source: In addition, those arguments are not constrained to be the same type.
trans-unit.target: In addition, those arguments are not constrained to be the same type.

trans-unit.source: Let's look at two examples.
trans-unit.target: Let's look at two examples.

trans-unit.source: The first example shows a class that generates values for a Mandelbrot set.
trans-unit.target: The first example shows a class that generates values for a Mandelbrot set.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the mathematics behind the set, read [this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandelbrot_set).
trans-unit.target: For more information on the mathematics behind the set, read [this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandelbrot_set).

trans-unit.source: The indexer uses two doubles to define a point in the X, Y plane.
trans-unit.target: The indexer uses two doubles to define a point in the X, Y plane.

trans-unit.source: The get accessor computes the number of iterations until a point is determined to be not in the set.
trans-unit.target: The get accessor computes the number of iterations until a point is determined to be not in the set.

trans-unit.source: If the maximum iterations is reached, the point is in the set, and the class's maxIterations value is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the maximum iterations is reached, the point is in the set, and the class's maxIterations value is returned.

trans-unit.source: (The computer generated images popularized for the Mandelbrot set define colors for the number of iterations necessary to determine that a point is outside the set.
trans-unit.target: (The computer generated images popularized for the Mandelbrot set define colors for the number of iterations necessary to determine that a point is outside the set.

trans-unit.source: The Mandelbrot Set defines values at every (x,y) coordinate for real number values.
trans-unit.target: The Mandelbrot Set defines values at every (x,y) coordinate for real number values.

trans-unit.source: That defines a dictionary that could contain an infinite number of values.
trans-unit.target: That defines a dictionary that could contain an infinite number of values.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, there is no storage behind the set.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, there is no storage behind the set.

trans-unit.source: Instead, this class computes the value for each point when code calls the `get` accessor.
trans-unit.target: Instead, this class computes the value for each point when code calls the `get` accessor.

trans-unit.source: There's no underlying storage used.
trans-unit.target: There's no underlying storage used.

trans-unit.source: Let's examine one last use of indexers, where the indexer takes multiple arguments of different types.
trans-unit.target: Let's examine one last use of indexers, where the indexer takes multiple arguments of different types.

trans-unit.source: Consider a program that manages historical temperature data.
trans-unit.target: Consider a program that manages historical temperature data.

trans-unit.source: This indexer uses a city and a date to set or get the high and low temperatures for that location:
trans-unit.target: This indexer uses a city and a date to set or get the high and low temperatures for that location:

trans-unit.source: This example creates an indexer that maps weather data on two different arguments: a city (represented by a `string`) and a date (represented by a `DateTime`).
trans-unit.target: This example creates an indexer that maps weather data on two different arguments: a city (represented by a `string`) and a date (represented by a `DateTime`).

trans-unit.source: The internal storage uses two `Dictionary` classes to represent the two-dimensional dictionary.
trans-unit.target: The internal storage uses two `Dictionary` classes to represent the two-dimensional dictionary.

trans-unit.source: The public API no longer represents the underlying storage.
trans-unit.target: The public API no longer represents the underlying storage.

trans-unit.source: Rather, the language features of indexers enables you to create a public interface that represents your abstraction, even though the underlying storage must use different core collection types.
trans-unit.target: Rather, the language features of indexers enables you to create a public interface that represents your abstraction, even though the underlying storage must use different core collection types.

trans-unit.source: There are two parts of this code that may be unfamiliar to some developers.
trans-unit.target: There are two parts of this code that may be unfamiliar to some developers.

trans-unit.source: These two `using` statements:
trans-unit.target: These two `using` statements:

trans-unit.source: create an *alias* for a constructed generic type.
trans-unit.target: create an *alias* for a constructed generic type.

trans-unit.source: Those statements enable the code later to use the more descriptive `DateMeasurements` and `CityDateMeasurements` names instead of the generic construction of `Dictionary<DateTime, Measurements>` and `Dictionary<string, Dictionary<DateTime, Measurements> >`.
trans-unit.target: Those statements enable the code later to use the more descriptive `DateMeasurements` and `CityDateMeasurements` names instead of the generic construction of `Dictionary<DateTime, Measurements>` and `Dictionary<string, Dictionary<DateTime, Measurements> >`.

trans-unit.source: This construct does require using the fully qualified type names on the right side of the `=` sign.
trans-unit.target: This construct does require using the fully qualified type names on the right side of the `=` sign.

trans-unit.source: The second technique is to strip off the time portions of any `DateTime` object used to index into the collections.
trans-unit.target: The second technique is to strip off the time portions of any `DateTime` object used to index into the collections.

trans-unit.source: The .NET framework does not include a Date only type.
trans-unit.target: The .NET framework does not include a Date only type.

trans-unit.source: Developers use the `DateTime` type, but use the `Date` property to ensure that any `DateTime` object from that day are equal.
trans-unit.target: Developers use the `DateTime` type, but use the `Date` property to ensure that any `DateTime` object from that day are equal.

trans-unit.source: Summing Up
trans-unit.target: Summing Up

trans-unit.source: You should create indexers anytime you have a property-like element in your class where that property represents not a single value, but rather a collection of values where each individual item is identified by a set of arguments.
trans-unit.target: You should create indexers anytime you have a property-like element in your class where that property represents not a single value, but rather a collection of values where each individual item is identified by a set of arguments.

trans-unit.source: Those arguments can uniquely identify which item in the collection should be referenced.
trans-unit.target: Those arguments can uniquely identify which item in the collection should be referenced.

trans-unit.source: Indexers extend the concept of [properties](properties.md), where a member is treated like a data item from outside the class, but like a method on the side.
trans-unit.target: Indexers extend the concept of [properties](properties.md), where a member is treated like a data item from outside the class, but like a method on the side.

trans-unit.source: Indexers allow arguments to find a single item in a property that represents a set of items.
trans-unit.target: Indexers allow arguments to find a single item in a property that represents a set of items.
